title-group.article-title: Dante Gabriel Rossetti and the Burdens of Nineveh

ref.mixed-citation: Saggs 1-9
Steindorff and Seele 1-10.
Kiernan also reminds us, "It was significant of Britain's prime concern with empire that from 1794 to 1854 it had a single Secretary of State for War and the Colonies" (17).
Bohrer's "A New Antiquity" (2: 244)
Jenkins, and Gadd (124-27 and 159-60).
His book, Orientalism and Visual Culture: Imagining Mesopotamia in Nineteenth Century Europe (Cambridge UP, 2003)
Stauffer; Bohrer, "A New Antiquity" 362-65
Layard's Discoveries 102-18.
Waterfield; and also Larsen, The Conquest of Assyria.
Macaulay's "Lays of Ancient Rome" (1847)
Keats's poems (1854).
Bohrer, "The Printed Orient," esp. 95-98
Nineveh Court 21
Russell, Sennacherib's Palace, chapter 5.
Nineveh and its Remains, facing page 451.
Layard discusses the image on pages 451-53.

Gadd has observed that "the closest parallel to the Frontispiece of Layard's second volume is the scene depicted on slabs of Sennacherib's palace at Nineveh, showing these same huge stones being hauled into their place by the enslaved enemies of the Assyrians; the wheels on the cart and some details of costume are almost the only difference in twenty-six centuries" (38).
Barclay; Bentley; Black 141^45
Rees 52-56
Woodring; Bohrer, "Assyria as Art," esp. 24
Larsen "Seeing Mesopotamia," esp. 107-16.
his Letters, 1: 91-93.
The P.R.B. Journal (82)
W. M. Rossetti's Dante Gabriel Rossetti as Designer and Writer (137-38).

Punch ventured a similar prediction in August of 1856: "it is far from impossible that ages after revolted Australia has successfully invaded Britain, and made a converted Kangaroo the President of the Anglican Republic, the descendants of the invaders may respectfully admire these Nimroud marbles, and wonder that their forefathers left nothing of equal endurance" (31:71).
Bristow mistakenly asserts that the Assyrian bull "represented what was at the time believed to be the most ancient civilization on earth" (380).
Byron's Sardanapalus (V.i. 480-87)
William Michael Rossetti's letter (Rossetti Papers 454)
Bentley seems to have been the first to identify which stone bull Rossetti apparently saw (167-68).
Altholtz, esp. 28-31
Coleridge makes similar statements in his posthumously published Confessions of an Inquiring Spirit (41-42).
The Hosea prophecy further relates to Rossetti's poem, as Jehovah goes on to complain of the Israelites' backsliding, as they "sacrificed unto Baalim and burned incense to graven images" (11.2)
he threatens, "He shall not return into the land of Egypt, but the Assyrian shall be his king. . . . and the sword shall abide on his cities, and shall consume his branches and devour them" (11.5-6).
Boos, who has conducted the most thorough study of the changes Rossetti made to the poem, cites the lines in question only to remark that the alterations "increase the musicality of lines" (208-09).
Baum writes that "Egypt was old when Nineveh was still young. The reading in the version of 1856 was ambiguous" (115).
McGann's hypermedia project, The Rossetti Archive.
Troxell, 179
Fraser, 160
Keane, 195ff.
Rossetti's "increasingly more accurate understanding of the irreverent and hostile undertaking of museum acquisition" (144).
Graves 294-303
Keats's influence on Rossetti, with special reference to "The Burden of Nineveh" on pages 138-39.
Bristow (380-81)
Harrison (102-03)

Kelley who reads Keats's sonnet as highly equivocal with regard to the Marbles and Romantic Hellenism generally, particularly in that it "collapses Egyptian and Greek antiquity into a single frame" (221).
Hellas (1821)
Shelley's Prose 332
Dante Gabriel Rossetti 62-65

Russell has shown in The Final Sack of Nineveh, our modern ignorance has contributed to the destruction of the Sennacherib Palace Site, which he calls "a world heritage disaster of the first magnitude" (49).

he writes, the archive of Assyrian stones and monuments "endured largely intact for millennia, until 1991, when we began in earnest to destroy it, unread_To the age-old question 'Where do I come from?' we will at last be able to provide a final answer: 'I don't know - we burned the library'" (51).
Black, 142ff.
Bohrer, "Times and Spaces."
Fisher discusses Keats's "Ode on a Grecian Urn"
